labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix

issues.title: Dhruv comments
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
- The phrasing "..few amount of network incidents.." is a bit odd.
- There is a singular module defined in the I-D, but the abstract says plural "modules". 
- Recheck the reference at "L3VPN services related with the interface will become unavailable [I-D.ietf-ippm-pam]" or expand the text to correlate with the reference. 
- BCP14 template is repeated twice in Section 2
- Section 7, please regenerate the tree, as it does not match the YANG module. For instance there is no leaf called "csn"...
- Section 7.1 claims that there are two YANG modules "ietf-incident-type" and "ietf-incident" but the actual module in section 8 is a merged one.  
- Section 7.{4,5}, some text needs to be added on the asynchronous nature of these RPC and how the incident client would learn about the output of these rpcs?
- Section 8, update the WG details in the YANG module; the yang file formatting is off (use this command "pyang --ietf --lint -f yang --keep-comments --yang-line-length 69 " to fix that); 
- Is cross-domain == multi-layer (Section 3.3)? Think about making that clear.  Perhaps you should differentiate between inter-domain and inter-layer?
- Is cause-name some well known cause or just free form string? (same for incident's name)
- Please add a description for what are root-events and how it relates to root-cause 
- Section 9, security consideration is just the template, actual analysis is missing
- Section 10, please fix the formatting of the IANA registry
- Please run a grammar check tool
- Please add JSON or XML examples

issues.title: Qiufang's comments

issues.title: One or more data models
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
https://github.com/ietf-wg-nmop/draft-ietf-nmop-network-incident-yang/blob/4c252f9fa986da5656ffedd463531640ea9e8fe4/draft-ietf-nmop-network-incident-yang.md?plain=1#L130

The title suggests that one model is defined but the abstract talks about many. Please align

issues.title: resolve network incidents
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
> management.  The YANG modules are meant to provide a standard way to
> report, diagnose, and resolve network incidents for the sake of
> network service health and root cause analysis.

I don't think YANG modules "resolve network incident" but feed that process

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
You are probably right, Some incidents can be Resolved automatically in the incident management server, but it 
should get instructions from the Customer/Incident management client. for some incidents which can not be resolved, it needs to escalate to report. In you words, feed the process.
Maybe I should reword as help resolve network incidents?

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
Fixed in the following two commits.
https://github.com/ietf-wg-nmop/draft-ietf-nmop-network-incident-yang/commit/df5c970037551cca52a6923ceb5ec2240ec8300b
https://github.com/ietf-wg-nmop/draft-ietf-nmop-network-incident-yang/commit/d7508db85859c3f5e5436ae351b0c6cdc365ac3a

issues.title: assess claimed benefits
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
Many benefits are claimed in the intro and the sample use cases. I know this is -00, but it is not obvious how some of these claims are met with the architecture/YANG module. 

Softening the tone would be required in some parts, but ...

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body: Sure, have fixed in the latest version.

issues.title: incident-id vs incident-no
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
https://github.com/ietf-wg-nmop/draft-ietf-nmop-network-incident-yang/blob/4c747144c025fc24bd4245ca0a4e1afa53ffbbf3/yang/ietf-incident.yang#L819C12-L819C22

What is the link between these two? Are these overlapping? If not, we need to explain what we have both. Thanks.

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body: Clarify the relationship between incident-no and incident-id, incident-id is optional qualifier and can be empty string while incident no is sequence number or serial number which is mandatory to have. I have made changes to both tree diagram and YANG model source code to reflect this.

issues.title: pyang-lint tool issue needs to be fixed first
issues.author: billwuqin
issues.body:
https://github.com/ietf-wg-nmop/draft-ietf-nmop-network-incident-yang/actions/runs/9525777377/job/26260370518
I check with Martin, he provide one workaround as follows:
@billwuqin, that's certainly a viable strategy. This pull request is a bit old, which means that it isn't necessarily how you would do it today.

You might do better with integrating the lint more tightly as I describe [in the documentation](https://github.com/martinthomson/i-d-template/blob/main/doc/TOOLS.md#linting-tools). For something like pyang-lint, you can get automated installation as described on the same page or in [the sourcecode](https://github.com/martinthomson/i-d-template/blob/main/deps.mk).

That means that you would only need to create a requirements.txt and add a rule approximately like:

yang-files := $(wildcard *.yang)
yang-file-markers := $(patsubst %.yang,.%.yang-lint,$(yang-files))
.PHONY: pyang-lint
pyang-lint: $(pyang-lint-files)
.%.yang-lint: %.yang $(DEPS_FILES)
        pyang-lint $< | tee $@
lint:: pyang-lint
(I haven't debugged the above, but I hope that it is clear enough.)

issues.title: Sync with TMF (See LS received 16/07/2024)
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
Per: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/nmop/LVZmlNOjDFjx3PqRLrjvTSnWnWg/

> @authors of draft-ietf-nmop-network-incident-yang: Parts of the LS are relevant to the scope of the incident mgt draft. Sharing your thoughts and candidate actions would be appreciated. Thanks.

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
@Med
First, it looks the current draft has already aligned with what TMF incident management API profile is doing, see annex A of LS, I agree the mapping between IETF Incident management and TMF API management is correct. It is not clear what else we need to do to make further alignment.
For the terminology, we referenced to both TMF incident terminology and IETF incident terminology work. Do we need to only reference IETF incident terminology work, it could be.

Secondly, I think IETF incident management work focuses on network level incident management, will not be tied with OSS or under the control of OSS, We have made change to reflect in the latest version which hasn't been submitted yet, e.g., single domain close loop, multi-domain close loop scenarios.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: (as induvial) may be it is worth to echo this in the draft?

comments.body: Thanks, the editorial changes look great.
